channel.title: Comments on: Testing Asynchronous Javascript w/ Jasmine 2.0.0
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.description: It was accidental. Somehow it was completely invisible to me every time I looked at that code, right up until you pointed it out. I suspect I was debugging my toFail() extension, since the way you manage these changed from 1.3.1 to 2.0.0 and it probably was missing the first time I tried to run the tests.
item.content:encoded: It was accidental. Somehow it was completely invisible to me every time I looked at that code, right up until you pointed it out. I suspect I was debugging my toFail() extension, since the way you manage these changed from 1.3.1 to 2.0.0 and it probably was missing the first time I tried to run the tests.

item.title: By: Tomasz
item.dc:creator: Tomasz
item.description: Why is there this line in Jasmine 2.0 solution: console.log(expect());
item.content:encoded:
Why is there this line in Jasmine 2.0 solution:
console.log(expect());

item.title: By: Tom Chiverton
item.dc:creator: Tom Chiverton
item.description:
Ah ha, awesome.
I had been using expect("error handler").not.toBeDefined(); inside the promises error handler, but I think toFail() looks neater.
item.content:encoded:
Ah ha, awesome.

I had been using expect(“error handler”).not.toBeDefined(); inside the promises error handler, but I think toFail() looks neater.

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.content:encoded:
Yep, it’s not. It’s a matcher I added to force a failure. See the top of either spec file to see the details:

– 2.0 tests on github
– 1.3.1 tests on github

item.title: By: Tom Chiverton
item.dc:creator: Tom Chiverton
item.description: toFail() doesn't appear to be a matcher ?
item.content:encoded: toFail() doesn’t appear to be a matcher ?
